title: Deep Vein Thrombosis and Pulmonary Embolism
setup_script: A 45-year-old woman, one week after total knee replacement, presents with swelling and pain in her left calf. Today, she developed shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. She has been receiving prophylactic low-molecular-weight heparin. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for vital signs
dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 115 bpm, RR 24/min, Temp 37.2 °C, SpO₂ 90% on room air.
Left calf circumference greater than right, tender to palpation, Homan’s sign positive; lungs clear; tachycardic.
D-dimer 2.0 µg/mL (elevated), CBC normal, creatinine 1.0 mg/dL.
Venous duplex shows occlusive thrombus in the popliteal vein; CT pulmonary angiography demonstrates segmental pulmonary emboli.
Patient becomes hypotensive (BP 85/55), SpO₂ drops to 82% on RA, HR increases to 130 bpm.
Therapeutic heparin infusion started; patient stabilizes with improved oxygenation.
Reserved for hemodynamic instability; patient currently stable, so anticoagulation is appropriate.
Recent surgery noted; weigh bleeding risk. If anticoagulation contraindicated, IVC filter placement is an option.
PESI score calculated; patient is low risk, appropriate for anticoagulation and close monitoring.
Not indicated at this time since this is a provoked event.
Patient counseled on symptoms of recurrent PE and the importance of adherence to anticoagulation.
3 months of anticoagulation for provoked DVT/PE; extended if ongoing risk factors persist.
Early mobilization, mechanical prophylaxis, and proper chemoprophylaxis in future high-risk surgical settings.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of signs and symptoms of DVT and PE
Differentiating when thrombolysis or IVC filter is indicated
